en_first_half: "No taste for drawing!" replied Elinor, "why should you think so? en_second_half: ever been in the way of learning, I think he would have drawn very well. en_results_raw: Had he been exposed to the same advantages as some people, I do not mean you, I am sure you will not take it as an affront, but some people, who have had the most excellent opportunities, he would have been as highly accomplished as they are. He has a great deal of natural taste, I assure you, and a great pleasure in seeing the performances of other people. He is very fond of music, and I have often heard him express his admiration of some of the finest compositions. He has also a great taste for reading, and is particularly fond of the works of the great poets. His mind is not uncultivated, I assure you, and he has a great deal of natural genius, which, with proper cultivation, would have made him a very accomplished man. But, alas! he has not had the same advantages as some people, and therefore we must not expect him to be as highly accomplished. Still, I think he is a very agreeable man, and I am always pleased to see him. He has a great deal of good sense, and a great deal of natural taste, and I think he would be a very pleasant companion, if one could only get him to talk. But, unfortunately, he is rather shy, and does not like to be drawn out, which makes it rather difficult to get to know him well.

en_first_half: "I have frequently detected myself in such kind of mistakes," said Elinor, "in a total misapprehension of character in some point or other: fancying people so much more gay or grave, or ingenious or stupid than they really are,
en_second_half: and I can hardly tell why or in what the deception originated. Sometimes one is guided by what they say of themselves, and very frequently by what other people say of them, without giving oneself time to deliberate and judge."
en_results_raw: and I have usually found that I have been deceived by some exaggerated or distorted representation of them, which has led me to form an opinion that has no foundation in reality. It is a common error, I believe, to judge of people's characters from a few partial and imperfect observations, and to suppose that we can form a just estimate of their dispositions and qualities from a slight acquaintance. But experience has taught me that this is a very uncertain and fallible method of judging, and that it is much safer to suspend our opinion until we have had more opportunities of observing their conduct and behavior. I have known people who have been considered as very grave and serious, who have turned out to be quite frivolous and silly, and others who have been thought to be very stupid, who have proved to be highly intelligent and ingenious. It is a great mistake to judge of people by their appearance or by a few superficial qualities, and it is only by a long and intimate acquaintance that we can form a just and accurate estimate of their characters.

Me he encontrado con personas que al principio parecían ser muy serias, pero que resultaron tener un gran sentido del humor, y con otras que parecían muy amigables, pero que en realidad eran muy reservadas. Es importante no juzgar a las personas por su apariencia o por lo que otros dicen de ellas, sino por sus acciones y su comportamiento. De esta manera, podemos evitar cometer errores y formarnos una opinión más precisa de los demás. Además, es importante recordar que todos tenemos diferentes facetas y que no siempre mostramos nuestra verdadera personalidad en todo momento. La vida es un proceso de descubrimiento y aprendizaje, y es importante mantener una mente abierta y no juzgar a los demás de manera apresurada.

But I am convinced that to a true admirer of nature, it is not merely a vague pleasure that is derived from the possession of a favourite haunt, but a source of inspiration, a solace, and a comfort. The feelings that it awakens are too deep, too sacred, to be expressed in the cold, calculating language of criticism. They are the whispers of the heart, the sighs of the soul, the echoes of a thousand tender memories. And it is this, I believe, that makes the love of nature so essential to our well-being, so necessary to our happiness. For in its presence, we are reminded of the beauty, the wonder, and the mystery of life itself. We are drawn out of ourselves, and our petty cares and troubles, into a world of grandeur, of majesty, of awe-inspiring beauty. And it is this, I think, that makes the love of nature so enduring, so unchanging, so essential to our very existence.

en_first_half: Sir John never came to the Dashwoods without either inviting them to dine at the park the next day, or to drink tea with them that evening.
en_second_half: On the present occasion, for the better entertainment of their visitor, towards whose amusement he felt himself bound to contribute, he wished to engage them for both.
en_results_raw: His arrival was always a signal for merriment; and with the kindness of a true friend, he always brought some little offering of game or fruit from his own estate. The gentlemen would often accompany him back to the park, and spend the evening with him, while the ladies would either join them there, or remain at home, enjoying the quiet of their own fireside. On one of these occasions, as they were all sitting in the parlour at the Dashwoods', Sir John began to talk of his plans for the improvement of the park, and his schemes for the amusement of his friends during the coming winter. He was particularly anxious to have the Dashwoods' opinion on the subject, and begged them to tell him frankly what they thought of his ideas. Marianne, who had been listening with great interest, could not help but express her enthusiasm for the plan, and suggested several improvements of her own, which Sir John was delighted to hear. Elinor, on the other hand, was more cautious in her praise, and ventured to suggest that some of the schemes might be rather too ambitious, and that it would be wise to consider the expense and the practicality of the plans before putting them into action. Sir John listened attentively to their opinions, and thanked them for their candour, assuring them that he valued their advice above that of anyone else. The evening wore on, and the conversation turned to other subjects, but the Dashwoods could not help but feel grateful for the kindness and generosity of their friend, and for the pleasure of his company, which always brought such joy and warmth into their lives.

Her husband, Mr. Palmer, was a man of a very different disposition, being naturally of a sullen and taciturn nature, and only roused to anger or excitement by some great provocation. He was, however, a man of considerable sense and penetration, and was not easily deceived by the outward appearances of things. He had a keen eye for character, and was not often mistaken in his judgment of those with whom he came in contact. Despite his reserved and somewhat forbidding exterior, he had a strong sense of justice and was always willing to listen to reason and argument. His wife, on the other hand, was a woman of much weaker understanding, and was often led astray by her own prejudices and passions. She was, however, a woman of great beauty and charm, and was well aware of the power of her attractions, which she did not hesitate to use in order to get her own way. The Palmers had two children, a boy and a girl, who were both still young and in the early stages of their education. The boy, who was the elder of the two, was a lively and intelligent child, with a keen sense of curiosity and a love of learning. The girl, on the other hand, was more reserved and serious, with a strong sense of duty and a desire to please. Both children were much attached to their parents, and were deeply influenced by their example and teaching.

en_first_half: Elinor was not inclined, after a little observation, to give him credit for being so genuinely and unaffectedly ill–natured or ill–bred as he wished to appear. His temper might perhaps be a little soured by finding, like many others of his sex, that through some unaccountable bias in favour of beauty, he was the husband of a very silly woman,—but she knew that this kind of blunder was too common for any sensible man to
en_second_half: be lastingly hurt by it.— It was rather a wish of distinction, she believed, which produced his contemptuous treatment of every body, and his general abuse of every thing before him. It was the desire of appearing superior to other people. The motive was too common to be wondered at; but the means, however they might succeed by establishing his superiority in ill–breeding, were not likely to attach any one to him except his wife.
en_results_raw: attach much importance to it. She was willing to allow that he might have been disappointed in his expectations of a more equal and rational partner; but she was not disposed to suppose him so much in love with his own pride, or so unforgiving, as to be incapable of that degree of kindness and civility which, even in the most ill-assorted marriages, it is usual to observe. She was more willing to believe that his reserve arose from a consciousness of his own inferiority in point of sense, and a fear of being overpowered by the superior understanding of his wife. She was not aware of the extent of his dislike to her sister, nor of the motives which induced him to treat her with such coldness and disdain; but she was not so blind as to be ignorant of the fact itself, and she was not so weak as to be intimidated by it. She knew that she had done nothing to deserve such treatment, and she was determined to bear it with the dignity and composure which became her character.

es_first_half: Tras observarlo durante un breve lapso, Elinor no estaba tan dispuesta a darle a él crédito por ser tan genuina y naturalmente de mal talante y mal educado como deseaba aparecer. Puede que su temperamento se hubiera agriado algo al descubrir, como tantos otros de su sexo, que por un inexplicable prejuicio en favor de la belleza, se encontraba casado con una mujer muy tonta; pero ella sabía que esta clase de desatino era demasiado común para que un hombre sensato se sintiera
es_second_half: afectado por mucho tiempo. Más bien era un deseo de distinción, creía, lo que lo inducía a ser tan displicente con todo el mundo y a su generalizado desprecio por todo lo que se le ponía por delante. Era el deseo de parecer superior a los demás. El motivo era demasiado corriente para que causara sorpresa; pero los medios, aunque tuvieran éxito en establecer su superioridad en mala crianza, no parecían adecuados para ganarle el aprecio de nadie que no fuera su mujer.
es_results_raw: permanentemente deprimido por él. Además, había algo en su comportamiento que sugería que no era un hombre completamente desprovisto de sentimientos, y que su rudeza era más una máscara que una característica inherente a su naturaleza. Elinor se preguntó si no sería posible que, bajo su áspera apariencia, se escondiera un hombre más complejo y sensible de lo que aparentaba. Su curiosidad estaba piquada, y se encontró deseando conocerlo mejor, a pesar de la primera impresión desfavorable que había tenido de él. Mientras continuaba observándolo, comenzó a notar pequeños detalles en su comportamiento que parecían contradecir su inicial impresión. Su forma de tratar a los sirvientes, por ejemplo, era más amable de lo que cabría esperar de un hombre de su talante, y su manera de hablar, aunque brusca, no carecía de cierta inteligencia y agudeza. Elinor se dio cuenta de que estaba empezando a encontrarlo interesante, y se preguntó si no sería posible que, con el tiempo, llegara a descubrir un lado más agradable de su personalidad.

The colour had fled from her cheeks, and her lips were pale and trembling, but she stood upright and still, like a statue, while the tears streamed down her face. Her sister, who had been watching her with anxious eyes, now rose and went to her, and gently drew her arm within her own, and led her from the room. Every view of the subject relative to your brother's situation leads to the same conclusion - that it is a most fortunate one, and that you may yet be happy. You have no doubt of your own merit, no reason to suppose yourself unworthy of a good husband; and you have the means of securing one. Your age, your character, and your connections, all promise you a most respectable and happy marriage. You have only to be guided by your own sense and discretion, and you will be sure to do what is right. Do not, however, suppose that I shall be an indifferent spectator of your proceedings. I shall watch them with the greatest interest, and shall be ready to give you my advice and assistance whenever you may need them. I shall also endeavour to discover the real character of the gentleman you may be inclined to favour, and shall not hesitate to warn you of any thing that may appear to me to be detrimental to your happiness. You may rely on my secrecy and my zeal for your welfare, and I hope that you will not refuse my aid when it is offered to you. I am, dear Marianne, your sincere friend and well-wisher.

I am not a man of many words, but I must say this to you. I must tell you that I have long admired your virtues, and that I have long wished to be of service to you. I know that I am not worthy of your notice, but I hope that you will not reject my offer. I hope that you will allow me to be your friend, and to be of some use to you in this time of sorrow. en_first_half: "His character is now before you; expensive, dissipated, and worse than both. Knowing all this, as I have now known it many weeks, guess what I must have felt on seeing your sister as fond of him as ever, and on being assured that she was to marry him: guess what I must have felt for all your sakes. When I came to you last week and found you alone, I came determined to know the truth; though irresolute what to do when it WAS known. My behaviour must have seemed strange to you then; but now you will comprehend it. To suffer you all to be so deceived; to see your sister—but what could I do? I had no hope of interfering with success; and sometimes I thought your sister's influence might yet reclaim him. But now, after such dishonorable usage, who can tell what were his designs on her. Whatever they may have been, however, she may now, and hereafter doubtless WILL turn with gratitude towards her own condition, when she compares it with that of
en_second_half: my poor Eliza, when she considers the wretched and hopeless situation of this poor girl, and pictures her to herself, with an affection for him so strong, still as strong as her own, and with a mind tormented by self–reproach, which must attend her through life. Surely this comparison must have its use with her. She will feel her own sufferings to be nothing. They proceed from no misconduct, and can bring no disgrace. On the contrary, every friend must be made still more her friend by them. Concern for her unhappiness, and respect for her fortitude under it, must strengthen every attachment. Use your own discretion, however, in communicating to her what I have told you. You must know best what will be its effect; but had I not seriously, and from my heart believed it might be of service, might lessen her regrets, I would not have suffered myself to trouble you with this account of my family afflictions, with a recital which may seem to have been intended to raise myself at the expense of others."

"Tuần rồi khi tôi đến đây và thấy cô chỉ có một mình, tôi đến với chủ định tìm hiểu sự thật; tuy không rõ mình sẽ làm gì một khi đã biết sự thật đau lòng. Lúc ấy cử chỉ của tôi hẳn là kỳ lạ đối với cô, nhưng bây giờ cô đã hiểu tại sao. Làm cho hai cô đau khổ thấy bị lừa dối như thế; thấy em gái cô... nhưng tôi làm gì được? es_first_half: —Ahora puede ver cómo es su carácter: derrochador, licencioso, y peor aún que eso. Sabiéndolo, como yo lo he sabido desde hace ya muchas semanas, imagínese lo que debo haber sentido al ver a su hermana tan afecta a él como siempre, y cuando se me aseguró que iba a casarse con él; imagínese lo que habré sentido pensando en todas ustedes. Cuando vine a verla la semana pasada y la encontré sola, estaba decidido a saber la verdad, aunque aún indeciso en cuanto a qué hacer cuando la supiera. Mi comportamiento debe haberle extrañado, pero ahora lo entenderá. Tener que verlas a todas ustedes engañadas en esa forma; ver a su hermana... pero, ¿qué podía hacer? No tenía esperanza alguna de intervenir con éxito; y en ocasiones pensaba que su hermana aún podía mantener suficiente influencia sobre él para recuperarlo. Pero tras un trato tan ignominioso, ¿quién sabe cuáles serían sus intenciones hacia ella? Cualesquiera hayan sido, sin embargo, puede que ahora ella se sienta agradecida de su situación, y sin duda más adelante lo estará, cuando la compare con la de mi pobre Eliza, cuando
es_second_half: piense en la situación miserable y desesperada de esta pobre niña y se la imagine con un afecto tan fuerte por él, tan fuerte como el que ella misma le tiene, y con un espíritu atormentado por las autorrecriminaciones, que la acompañarán durante toda su vida. Con toda seguridad esta comparación le servirá de algo. Sentirá que sus propios sufrimientos no son nada. No provienen de una mala conducta y no pueden traerle desgracia. Al contrario, deberán hacer que en cada uno de sus amigos aumente la amistad hacia ella. La preocupación por su desdicha y el respeto por la entereza que subyace a ella deberán reforzar todos los afectos. Utilice, sin embargo, su propia discreción para comunicarle lo que le he contado. Usted debe saber mejor qué efecto tendrá; y si no hubiera creído muy seriamente y desde el fondo de mi corazón que pudiera serle de alguna utilidad, que pudiera aliviar sus padecimientos, no me habría permitido perturbarla con este relato de las aflicciones que ha debido sufrir mi familia, una narración con la cual podría sospecharse que intento enaltecerme a costa de los demás.
es_results_raw: se entere de todo. Mi pobre Eliza, que siempre fue una muchacha tan buena y tan amable, y que nunca tuvo una oportunidad en la vida. Su madre murió cuando era apenas una niña, y su padre, que siempre fue un hombre débil y sin principios, la dejó en mi cuidado cuando se fue a buscar fortuna en el extranjero. Yo la crié como a una hija, y siempre la traté con el mismo cariño y respeto que a mis propias hijas. Pero, a pesar de todo, ella siempre se sintió atraída por ese hombre, y ahora... ahora es demasiado tarde. La he perdido para siempre, y no puedo sino culpar a su hermana por no haberla disuadido de semejante unión. ¿Cómo pudo permitir que su hermana se casara con un hombre así? ¿Cómo pudo ser tan ciega ante sus defectos y su mala conducta? Pero supongo que el amor es ciego, y que la juventud y la inexperiencia pueden llevar a cometer errores terribles.

en_first_half: Marianne had promised to be guided by her mother's opinion, and she submitted to it therefore without opposition, though it proved perfectly different from what she wished and expected, though she felt it to be entirely wrong, formed on mistaken grounds, and
en_second_half: that by requiring her longer continuance in London it deprived her of the only possible alleviation of her wretchedness, the personal sympathy of her mother, and doomed her to such society and such scenes as must prevent her ever knowing a moment's rest.
en_results_raw: that it would bring her little peace, and probably much pain. She was to see him, however, and to see him surrounded by those who would make his presence a torment, and who would themselves be the greatest sufferers from the visit. Her mother was anxious to show a distinction in her favour, and to make her see that she was not slighted or neglected, and that every attention was still to be paid to her. Marianne was to be treated with the same respect and consideration as before, and her mother was determined to convince her that she was not less dear to her than she had ever been. But Marianne knew that this was impossible, and that she could never be to her what she had been before. She was to be pitied and consoled, and her mother was to be the one to do it, but she could not help feeling that it was all a sham, and that her mother's words and actions were not sincere. She was to be treated with kindness and compassion, but she knew that it was all a pretence, and that her mother's real feelings were very different. She was to be made to see that she was still loved and valued, but she knew that it was all a lie, and that she was nothing but a burden to her mother. And so she submitted to her mother's wishes, and agreed to see him, though she knew it would bring her nothing but pain and sorrow.

She was, in short, a young woman of a very easy and accommodating disposition, who was always contented with what was, and never troubled herself about what might be. She was not, indeed, very clever, nor very wise, nor very witty; but she was very good-natured, and very good-humoured; and she was always ready to do what she could to oblige her sister, and to make her happy. She was, in fact, a very pleasant and a very agreeable companion; and though she was not very brilliant, nor very distinguished, she was very well liked, and very well respected, by all who knew her.

en_first_half: "Yes; once, while she was staying in this house, I happened to drop in for ten minutes; and I saw quite enough of her. I offered immediately, as soon as my mother related the affair to me, to talk to him myself, and dissuade him from the match; but it was too late THEN, I found, to do any thing, for unluckily, I was not in the way at first, and knew nothing of it till after the
en_second_half: breach had taken place, when it was not for me, you know, to interfere. But had I been informed of it a few hours earlier—I think it is most probable—that something might have been hit on. I certainly should have represented it to Edward in a very strong light. 'My dear fellow,' I should have said, 'consider what you are doing. You are making a most disgraceful connection, and such a one as your family are unanimous in disapproving.' I cannot help thinking, in short, that means might have been found. But now it is all too late. He must be starved, you know;—that is certain; absolutely starved."

es_first_half: —Sí, una vez, cuando estaba alojada en esta casa. Me había dejado caer por unos diez minutos, y me bastó con lo que vi de ella. Una simple muchacha pueblerina, desmañada, sin estilo ni elegancia, y casi sin ningún atractivo. La recuerdo perfectamente. Justo el tipo de muchacha que habría creído capaz de cautivar al pobre Edward. Apenas mi madre me contó todo el asunto, de inmediato me ofrecí— a hablarle, a disuadirlo de la unión; pero, según pude darme cuenta, ya era demasiado tarde para hacer algo, pues por desgracia no estuve ahí en los primeros momentos y no supe nada
es_second_half: de lo ocurrido hasta después de la ruptura, cuando, ya sabe usted, no me correspondía interferir. Pero si se me hubiera informado unas pocas horas antes, probablemente habría podido hacer algo. De todas maneras le habría hecho ver las cosas a Edward con toda claridad. “Mi querido amigo”, le habría dicho, “piensa en lo que haces. Estás comprometiéndote en la más desafortunada unión, que toda tu familia desaprueba de manera unánime”. En fin, no puedo evitar pensar que habría encontrado alguna manera de lograrlo. Pero ahora es demasiado tarde. Debe estar muerto de hambre, sabe usted; con toda seguridad, absolutamente muerto de hambre.

Mi madre me dijo que Edward se había enamorado perdidamente de ella desde el primer momento en que la vio, y que no había forma de hacer que cambiara de opinión. Me contó que había intentado hablar con él, pero que él no la escuchaba. Me dijo que estaba decidido a casarse con ella, sin importar lo que nadie dijera. Me sentí muy triste al escuchar esto, porque sabía que Edward se estaba equivocando. Pero, como no podía hacer nada para detenerlo, decidí no intervenir y dejar que las cosas siguieran su curso. Ahora, al ver a la muchacha en la casa, no puedo evitar sentir una mezcla de tristeza y decepción. Me pregunto cómo alguien como Edward, que siempre había sido tan sensato y juicioso, pudo caer en un error tan grande. Me pregunto qué habrá visto en ella que lo hizo enamorarse de esa manera. Me pregunto si alguna vez se dará cuenta de su error y si podrá recuperarse de esta unión desafortunada. Pero, por ahora, solo puedo observar y esperar, sin poder hacer nada para cambiar el curso de los acontecimientos.
